lines.text: Dinah, Please tell them that I'm Cantor and I'll double your salary.
I don't know who you are, but if you'll double my salary, you're certainly not Cantor!

[after an effort at being tough has no effect whatsoever]
Hey, I must be losing my touch!
What Dr. Schlenna is trying to say is that we are using motion picture names exclusively...
'Motion pi-'! I've been a picture star for years! Wouldn't you call *me* a name?
Oh, definitely - but not the kind I can put in lights.
Now, don't be impatient! Dr. Kirby will be here in a few minutes.
Dr. Kirby? Listen -
[sitting up]

[pushing him back on gurney]
Down!
You don't understand!
[sitting up]

[pushing him back on gurney]
Down!
This is all a mistake!
[sitting up]

[pushing him back on gurney]
Down!

[flailing his legs and sobbing]
Oh-hoh-hoh-hoh-hoh!

[as all three hold down his legs]
And don't kick!

[sitting up]
I always kick on the fourth down.
Ah, my favorite scalpel. Who's the patient?
Eddie Cantor.
Ha-ha-ha-ha! Start the anesthetic.
How about it, soldier? Show the little lady all the homes of the movie stars?
I'm sorry, Mac. I got an hour. I gotta get back to my ship.
What better way can you spend your last hour than a nice bus ride.

[Arm in arm with a beautiful blonde]
Are you kidding?
Why don't you want me? Why?
Well, Mr. cantor, to be brutally frank, you have the reputation of taking over everything you participate in.
Farnsworth, I got you into this complication, and it's up to me to make a mess out of it.
An Indian comes up to me and says it's tough for us Indians. I said, "You don't like it here, why don't you go back where you came from?"

[regarding Cantor]
According to his pulse, he's been dead for 43 weeks.

[On the phone, posing as a fictitious Southern reporter for a non-existent newspaper]
Mr. Cantor, sir, this is Colonel Robert E. Jefferson of the Montgomery Post Gazette. What we all down here wants, from you all up there, is the complete story of your life, sir... Now, you begin right at the beginning, sir, and don't omit any of the details, no matter how boring they may be, sir. Yes, sir.
Fine! Well, Colonel, my ancestors crossed the Plains in the first covered wagon. If you ever saw my ancestors, you'd understand *why* the wagon was covered - huh, huh, huh!... Don't print that!
Let's just do it the way we did in rehearsals.
But you'll be hiding my face!

[Shoves him against the wall]
Is that bad?
Let's talk about my salary.
Oh, let's not argue about that! How much do you want?
Five thousand bucks.
Let's argue.
